<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The Company elected to consolidate the results of two of the
    businesses acquired through the HNC separation and termination
    agreement as though the transaction had occurred at the
    beginning of the 2006 fiscal year instead of the date of
    acquisition. The increases in revenues and operating income that
    resulted from the election were offset in the statement of
    operations by pre-acquisition interests, net of tax. See
    Note&#160;7, &#147;Business Combinations&#148;, of the Notes to
    Consolidated Financial Statements in Item&#160;8 Financial
    Statements and Supplementary Data.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    As a result of the HNC joint venture separation and termination
    agreement, the Joint Venture segment was eliminated and the
    results for the two entities acquired in this transaction, in
    which the Company had a previous interest, and all remaining
    Joint Ventures were consolidated into the Metals Recycling
    Business as of the beginning of fiscal 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (3) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Corporate expense consists primarily of unallocated corporate
    expense for services that benefit all three business segments.
    Because of this unallocated expense, the operating income of
    each segment does not reflect the operating income the segment
    would have as a stand-alone business.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    32
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (4) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Recycled ferrous metal sales from the Metals Recycling Business
    to the Steel Manufacturing Business and autobody sales from the
    Auto Parts Business to the Metals Recycling Business are made at
    negotiated rates per ton that are intended to approximate
    market. Consequently, these intercompany revenues produce
    intercompany operating income, which is not recognized until the
    finished products are sold to third parties.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Fiscal
    2006 Compared to Fiscal 2005</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Revenues.</I>&#160;&#160;Consolidated revenues for fiscal
    2006 increased to $1,855&#160;million, which is a
    $1,002&#160;million, or 117%, change from the prior year. The
    increase in revenues is primarily a result of the current year
    acquisitions in the Metals Recycling Business and Auto Parts
    Business. The Steel Manufacturing business also contributed to
    additional revenues as a result of increased production from its
    existing facility.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Metals Recycling Business generated revenues of
    $1,407&#160;million for fiscal 2006, before intercompany
    eliminations, which was an increase of $827&#160;million, or
    142%, over the prior year. Ferrous revenues were
    $1,132&#160;million, which was an increase of $644&#160;million,
    or 132%. This increase was a result of the acquisition-related
    volume increases, which was offset partially by the decrease in
    the average net sales price for ferrous metal. Ferrous volumes
    increased to 4,561&#160;million tons sold, which was a
    2,696&#160;million ton, or 145%, increase over prior year,
    primarily as a result of sales by acquired entities. The average
    net sales price for processed ferrous metal decreased to
    $215&#160;per ton in fiscal 2006 from $230&#160;per ton in
    fiscal 2005, a change of 6%, which was entirely market driven.
    Beginning with the fourth quarter of 2005, worldwide markets for
    ferrous scrap metal softened slightly due to lower demand from
    Asian customers, with average prices declining through the
    second quarter of 2006. However, beginning with the third
    quarter demand began to increase and by the fourth quarter
    average prices were higher than realized during the early part
    of 2005. The global trade operation acquired from HNC
    contributed $330&#160;million in revenues in fiscal 2006, based
    on ferrous sales of approximately 1.3&#160;million tons.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Nonferrous revenues were $267&#160;million, which was an
    increase of $196&#160;million, or 277%, over the prior year.
    This increase was a result of the increase of sales by acquired
    entities and an increase in the sale price of nonferrous
    revenues. Nonferrous volumes increased to approximately
    302&#160;million pounds sold which was a 176&#160;million pound,
    or 140%, increase over prior year, primarily as a result of
    sales by acquired entities. The volumes from Regional and the
    operations acquired in the HNC separation and termination
    contributed $164&#160;million of the increase in nonferrous
    revenues for the year. The average net sales price for
    nonferrous metal increased to $0.87&#160;per pound in fiscal
    2006 from $0.56&#160;per pound in fiscal 2005, a change of 57%,
    which, similar to the change in ferrous prices, was entirely
    market driven. During 2006, the demand for recycled nonferrous
    metals such as copper, tin and aluminum used in manufacturing
    increased significantly, leading to significantly higher prices.
    In addition, through the Company&#146;s acquisition of Regional
    during 2006, purchases of higher grade nonferrous material
    increased, which contributed to an increase in overall average
    prices for nonferrous sales.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The amount billed to customers for freight that was included in
    revenues increased to $139&#160;million, which was an increase
    of $80&#160;million, or 135%, over the prior year. Of that
    amount, $48&#160;million is a result of current year
    acquisitions and $32&#160;million is due to an increase in the
    number of ferrous shipments in fiscal 2006 over fiscal 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Metals Recycling Business sold 668,000 tons of ferrous metal
    to the Steel Manufacturing Business in fiscal 2006, which was a
    43,000 ton, or 7%, increase due to the increased demand for
    steel products.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In fiscal 2006, the Metals Recycling Business also recognized
    other revenues of $8&#160;million, a decrease of
    $13&#160;million, or 60%, compared to fiscal 2005. This decrease
    relates primarily to $15&#160;million of dealer brokerage
    commissions that were earned by the Company&#146;s Asian
    subsidiary for the sales of pig iron during 2005 that did not
    occur in 2006. These brokerage commissions were recorded as
    other revenues while the related cost was included in the
    Company&#146;s cost of goods sold for fiscal 2005. The remaining
    difference is primarily a result of additional docking fees that
    were earned by the Company during 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Auto Parts Business generated revenues of $218&#160;million,
    before intercompany eliminations, in fiscal 2006, which is an
    increase of $110&#160;million, or 102%, over the prior year.
    This increase was primarily a result of the acquisition of the
    full service auto parts stores in the current year, which
    accounted for $90&#160;million of the increase, coupled with a
    full year of operations of four self service stores that were
    acquired in January 2005.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    33
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Steel Manufacturing Business generated revenues of
    $387&#160;million for fiscal 2006, which was an increase of
    $71&#160;million, or 23%, over the prior fiscal year. This
    increase was a result of a 19% increase in the number of tons
    sold in the current year, coupled with an increase in the
    average net selling price year over year. The average net
    selling price increased to $528&#160;per ton, which represents a
    $16&#160;per ton, or 3%, increase over prior year and was due to
    a combination of factors including increased worldwide steel
    consumption and higher raw material costs that manufacturers
    passed through in the form of higher prices. Sales volumes
    increased to 703,000 tons, an increase over the prior year of
    110,000 tons or 19%. The increased sales volume was primarily
    due to increased demand from customers and capital improvements
    by the Company that enabled the steel mill to increase output to
    meet the demand.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Cost of Goods Sold.</I>&#160;&#160;Consolidated cost of goods
    sold increased to $1,527&#160;million, an $893&#160;million, or
    141%, change compared with fiscal 2005. Cost of goods sold
    increased as a percentage of revenues from 74% to 82%.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cost of goods sold for the Metals Recycling Business increased
    to $1,235&#160;million, which represents a $784&#160;million, or
    174%, change from fiscal 2005. The majority of the increase is
    attributable to current year acquisitions. As a percentage of
    revenues, cost of goods sold were 88% in fiscal 2006 compared to
    78% during fiscal 2005. The change is primarily attributable to
    the acquisitions, as Regional and the businesses acquired
    through the HNC separation and termination have been
    experiencing narrower operating margins than the Company&#146;s
    historical West Coast operations. The lower operating margins
    for these businesses are due, in part, to more competitive
    markets for materials in the Northeast and Southeast regions of
    the U.S., higher operating expenses at the Company&#146;s
    Everett, Massachusetts facility due to outdated and inefficient
    equipment and lower margins generally in the Company&#146;s
    ferrous metal trading activities. The Company has made
    substantial progress on a major capital improvement program to
    upgrade infrastructure and equipment in the newly-acquired
    Everett, Massachusetts and Johnston, Rhode Island facilities and
    throughout the Company in order to become more efficient and
    improve productivity. Compared with fiscal 2005, the average
    ferrous metal cost of goods sold per ton increased 3% due
    primarily due to higher purchase costs for unprocessed ferrous
    metal, while at the same time the average net sales price per
    ton declined 6%.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Auto Parts Business&#146; cost of goods sold increased to
    $142&#160;million in fiscal 2006, which represents a
    $78&#160;million, or 121%, change as compared to fiscal 2005.
    $63&#160;million of the total increase is attributable to the
    current year acquisition of the full service auto parts stores.
    As a percentage of revenues, cost of goods sold were 65% as
    compared to 59% in the fiscal 2005. The lower margins are
    primarily attributable to the Company&#146;s entry into the full
    service used parts market, which has higher costs associated
    with the purchase and removal of parts sold through the full
    service distribution model, and increased demand and competition
    for unprocessed metals which has increased the costs for the
    purchase of cars in the self service distribution model.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Steel Manufacturing Business&#146; cost of goods sold
    increased to $307&#160;million, a change of $38&#160;million, or
    14%, over fiscal 2005. As a percentage of revenues, cost of
    goods sold decreased to 79%, compared with 85% in fiscal 2005.
    The average cost of goods sold per ton decreased to
    $415&#160;per ton, a change of $8&#160;per ton, or 2%, compared
    to the prior year. The reduction reflects a combination of
    increased production (698,000 tons of steel production in fiscal
    2006 as compared to 618,000 tons in fiscal 2005)&#160;and
    reductions in labor costs, raw material and melt shop conversion
    costs reflecting the efficiencies gained with the installation
    of a new electric arc furnace during mid-fiscal 2005 and
    production incentives negotiated with the Company&#146;s
    production employees at the beginning of Fiscal 2006. Cost of
    electricity remained at 5% of cost of goods sold with natural
    gas increasing from 2% to 3% of cost of goods sold.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Selling, General and Administrative
    Expense.</I>&#160;&#160;In fiscal 2006, selling, general and
    administrative expense increased to $157&#160;million, which is
    a $99&#160;million, or 170%, change over fiscal 2005. Of this
    increase, $55&#160;million was selling, general and
    administrative expenses attributable to the operations of the
    acquired businesses. There was also a $15&#160;million increase
    over the prior year in expenses related to the investigations
    into the past practice of making improper payments to the
    purchasing managers of the Company&#146;s customers in Asia, as
    discussed in Note&#160;11, &#147;Commitments and
    Contingencies&#148;, of the Notes to Consolidated Financial
    Statements in Item&#160;8 Financial Statements and Supplementary
    Data. Additionally, increases of $7&#160;million was due to
    contract labor, legal and accounting fees mostly due to the ERP
    installation, $7&#160;million from salaries and bonuses for
    management and $3&#160;million from 123R expense recognized. As
    a percentage of revenues, selling, general and administrative
    expense has increased to 8% as compared to 7% in the prior year
    due to the previously mentioned items.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    34
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Environmental
    Matters</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During fiscal 2006, the Company recorded estimated environmental
    liabilities of $13&#160;million, $8&#160;million and
    $4&#160;million related to the Greenleaf, Regional and HNC
    acquisitions, respectively, based on due diligence performed in
    connection with these acquisitions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During fiscal 2005, the Company recorded environmental charges
    of $14&#160;million for additional estimated costs related to
    the ongoing remediation of the head of the Hylebos Waterway
    adjacent to the Company&#146;s Tacoma, Washington metal
    processing facility. An estimate of this liability was initially
    recognized as part of the 1995 acquisition of the Tacoma
    facility. The cost estimate was based on the assumption that
    dredge removal of contaminated sediments would be accomplished
    within one dredge season during July 2004&#160;&#151; February
    2005. However, due to a variety of factors, including dredge
    contractor operational issues and other dredge related delays,
    the dredging was not completed during the first dredge season.
    As a result, the Company increased its environmental accrual by
    $14&#160;million primarily to account for additional estimated
    costs to complete this work during a second dredging season. The
    Company has filed a lawsuit against the dredge contractor to
    recover a significant portion of the increased costs. During
    2006, the Company made $7&#160;million in payments, resulting in
    a reserve of $4&#160;million at August&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For a number of years prior to the Company&#146;s acquisition of
    Proler International Corp. (&#147;Proler&#148;), Proler operated
    an industrial waste landfill in Texas, which Proler utilized to
    dispose of auto shredder residue from one of its operations. In
    August 2002, Proler entered the TCEQ VCP toward the pursuit of
    the VCP Certificate of Completion for the former landfill site.
    In fiscal 2005, TCEQ issued a Conditional Certificate of
    Completion, requiring the Company to perform on-going
    groundwater monitoring and annual inspections, maintenance and
    reporting. As a result of the resolution of this issue, the
    Company reduced its reserve in 2005 related to this site by
    $2&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Portland Harbor.</I>&#160;&#160;In December 2000, the EPA
    designated the Portland Harbor, a 5.5&#160;mile stretch of the
    Willamette River in Portland, Oregon, as a Superfund site. The
    Company&#146;s metals recycling and deep water terminal facility
    in Portland, Oregon is located adjacent to the Portland Harbor.
    The EPA has identified at least 69&#160;PRPs, including the
    Company and Crawford Street Corporation (&#147;CSC&#148;), a
    subsidiary of the Company, which own and operate or formerly
    owned and operated sites adjacent to the Portland Harbor
    Superfund site. The precise nature and extent of any
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">clean-up</FONT> of
    the Portland Harbor, the parties to be involved, the process to
    be followed for such a clean-up, and the allocation of any costs
    for the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">clean-up</FONT>
    among responsible parties have not yet been determined. It is
    unclear whether or to what extent the Company or CSC will be
    liable for environmental costs or damages associated with the
    Superfund site. It is also unclear whether, or to what extent
    natural resource damage claims or third party contribution or
    damages claims will be asserted against the Company, as such, no
    reserve has been established. While the Company and CSC
    participated in certain preliminary Portland Harbor study
    efforts, they are not parties to the consent order entered into
    by the EPA with other PRPs (&#147;Lower Willamette Group&#148;
    or (&#147;LWG&#148;) for a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility
    Study (&#147;RI/FS&#148;)); however, the Company and CSC could
    become liable for a share of the costs of this study at a later
    stage of the proceedings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Separately, the Oregon Department of Environmental Quality
    (&#147;DEQ&#148;) has requested operating history and other
    information from numerous persons and entities which own or
    conduct operations on properties adjacent to or upland from the
    Portland Harbor, including the Company and CSC. The DEQ
    investigations at the Company and CSC sites are focused on
    controlling any current releases of contaminants into the
    Willamette River. The Company has agreed to a voluntary Remedial
    Investigation/Source Control effort with the DEQ regarding its
    Portland, Oregon deep water terminal facility and the site
    formerly owned by CSC. DEQ identified these sites as potential
    sources of contaminants that could be released into the
    Willamette River. The Company believes that improvements in the
    operations at these sites, often referred to as Best Management
    Practices (&#147;BMPs&#148;), will provide effective source
    control and avoid the release of contaminants from these sites
    and has proposed to DEQ the implementation of BMPs as the
    resolution of this investigation. Additionally, the EPA recently
    released and made available to the public the LWG&#146;s
    &#147;Round Two&#148; data, involving hundreds of sediment
    samples taken throughout the six mile harbor site. The Company
    is in the process of reviewing this data.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The cost of the investigations and remediation associated with
    these properties and the cost of employment of source control
    BMPs is not reasonably estimable until the completion of the
    data review. While the Company has
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    35
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    recorded a $1 million reserve for its estimated share of the
    costs of the investigation incurred to date by the LWG, no
    liability has been recorded for either future investigation
    costs or remediation of the Portland Harbor.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During fiscal 2006, the Company and CSC, together with
    approximately 27 PRPs who are not participating in the
    LWG&#146;s RI/FS, received letters from the LWG and one of its
    members with respect to participating in the LWG&#160;RI/FS and
    potential claims for past costs and cost allocation and
    reimbursement. If the Company or CSC&#160;declines to
    participate in the continued implementation of the RI/FS, it is
    possible that they could be the subject to EPA or DEQ
    enforcement orders or litigation by the LWG or its members. The
    Company is cooperating in discussions with the agencies and the
    LWG and continuing to evaluate alleged liabilities in the
    context of the available technical, factual and legal
    information.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Interest Expense.</I>&#160;&#160;Interest expense for fiscal
    2006 increased to $3&#160;million which is a change of
    $2&#160;million or 313% compared with fiscal 2005. The increase
    was a result of higher average debt balances during fiscal 2006
    compared with fiscal 2005 primarily to complete and integrate
    acquisitions as well as to support the increased level of
    working capital requirements for the operations of these
    acquisitions, and the Company&#146;s capital improvement program.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Income Tax Provision.</I>&#160;&#160;The 37% tax rate for
    fiscal 2006 is higher than the 35% for fiscal 2005 primarily
    because this year&#146;s effective tax rate was increased by the
    penalties and profits disgorgement expensed in connection with
    the making of improper payments to purchasing managers of
    $14&#160;million which is nondeductible (see Item&#160;3 Legal
    Proceedings). A secondary reason for the current year&#146;s
    increased effective tax rate is that the current year
    $57&#160;million gain from the disposition of joint venture
    interests (see Note&#160;7&#160;&#151; Business Combinations)
    will not likely benefit from either the Extraterritorial Income
    Exclusion on export sales or the Section&#160;199 domestic
    manufacturing deduction that reduces the Company&#146;s
    effective tax rate on other operating income.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The acquisition of GreenLeaf was a stock purchase which included
    Federal net operating losses (&#147;NOLs&#148;) of
    $15&#160;million that will expire in the years 2022 through 2024
    if not used before then. The Company&#146;s use of these NOLs is
    restricted under Federal income tax law to $1&#160;million a
    year.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Fiscal
    2005 Compared to Fiscal 2004</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Revenues.</I>&#160;&#160;Consolidated revenues for the year
    ended August&#160;31, 2005 increased $165&#160;million, or 24%,
    to $853&#160;million from $688&#160;million for the prior year.
    The higher revenues resulted from higher average net selling
    prices for the Metals Recycling Business and the Steel
    Manufacturing Business as well as higher wholesale and retail
    revenues for the Auto Parts Business. Revenues for fiscal 2005
    increased for the Metals Recycling Business, primarily as a
    result of increased prices in the worldwide ferrous metal
    market. Higher raw material costs and increasing steel
    consumption drove increases in selling prices for finished steel
    products sold by the Steel Manufacturing Business. Auto Parts
    Business revenues benefited from increased prices for sales of
    autobodies and other recycled metal. In addition, the Auto Parts
    Business acquired four retail locations in the second quarter of
    fiscal 2005 that added both revenue and operating income to the
    segment over the prior year.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Metals Recycling Business generated revenues of
    $580&#160;million for fiscal 2005, before intercompany
    eliminations, which was an increase of $124&#160;million, or
    27%, over the prior year. Ferrous revenues increased
    $95&#160;million, or 24%, to $488&#160;million as a result of
    higher average selling prices net of shipping costs (average net
    selling prices), higher shipping costs and a slight increase in
    the volume sold. The average net sales price for ferrous metal
    increased 25% to $230&#160;per ton over the prior year. The
    amount billed to customers for freight that was included in
    revenues increased by $5&#160;million over the prior year, due
    primarily to higher ocean chartering costs. Export shipping
    costs were volatile in fiscal 2005 and increased 9% on average
    over the prior year. Total ferrous sales volumes increased
    slightly by approximately 20,000 tons, or 1%, over the prior
    year.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Sales to the Steel Manufacturing Business increased by 8,000
    tons, or 1%, to 625,000 tons due to increased steel production
    as a result of the new furnace installed in December 2004,
    partially offset by reduced sales during the furnace replacement
    shut-down. Nonferrous revenue increased $14&#160;million, or
    24%, to $71&#160;million due to higher average selling prices
    and higher volumes. The average net nonferrous selling price in
    fiscal 2005 was $0.56&#160;per pound, an increase of
    $0.08&#160;per pound, or 17%. In addition, nonferrous sales
    volume increased 7% to 126&#160;million pounds. The increases in
    average selling price and volume are related to strong worldwide
    demand, especially from Asia, and improved by-product recoveries
    of nonferrous metal from the ferrous metal shredding process.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    36
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In fiscal 2005, the Metals Recycling Business also recognized
    other revenues of $21&#160;million, an increase of
    $15&#160;million, or 250% over fiscal 2004. The majority of the
    increase relates to the recording of certain sales by the
    Company&#146;s Asian subsidiary. Typically, this subsidiary
    serves as a broker and, as a result, any revenues recorded are
    normally limited to brokerage commissions. In fiscal 2005, the
    subsidiary made sales of pig iron as a dealer. Thus, the sales
    proceeds are included in revenues while the related cost is
    included in the Company&#146;s cost of goods sold for fiscal
    2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Auto Parts Business generated revenue of $108&#160;million,
    before intercompany eliminations, for the year ended
    August&#160;31, 2005, which is an increase of $26&#160;million,
    or 32%, over the prior year. This increase was a result of
    higher wholesale revenues driven by higher average sales prices
    for scrapped autobodies due to rising recycled ferrous metal
    prices and higher prices and volumes for wholesale parts. In
    addition, retail revenues increased as a result of the
    acquisition of four retail store locations in January 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Steel Manufacturing Business generated revenues of
    $315&#160;million for the year ended August&#160;31, 2005, which
    was an increase of $44&#160;million, or 16%, over the prior
    fiscal year. The average net selling price increased
    $108&#160;per ton, or 27%, to $512&#160;per ton. The increase in
    average net selling prices was due to a combination of factors,
    including increased worldwide steel consumption and higher raw
    material costs that manufacturers passed through in the form of
    higher prices. However, sales volumes decreased 8% to 593,000
    tons. The lower sales volume was primarily due to abnormally
    high inventory levels held by fabricators and distributors of
    steel during the first half of fiscal 2005. Many of the
    Company&#146;s customers used the normal seasonal decline in
    consumption during the winter months to reduce their inventory
    levels.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Cost of Goods Sold.</I>&#160;&#160;Consolidated cost of goods
    sold increased to $634&#160;million, a $98&#160;million change,
    or 18%, compared with fiscal 2004. Cost of goods sold decreased
    as a percentage of revenues from 77% to 73%.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Cost of goods sold for the Metals Recycling Business increased
    $78&#160;million, or 21%, to $451&#160;million. As a percentage
    of revenues, cost of goods sold decreased compared with fiscal
    2004 from 79% to 76%. Cost of goods sold was reduced by
    $8&#160;million in net inventory adjustments compared to
    $3&#160;million in inventory adjustments in fiscal 2004. During
    fiscal 2005, several piles of ferrous metal inventory were fully
    utilized, revealing higher inventory volumes than the
    Company&#146;s previous estimates, and thereby resulting in a
    credit to cost of goods sold. Compared with last year, the
    average ferrous metal cost of goods sold per ton increased 22%,
    due primarily to higher purchase costs for unprocessed ferrous
    metal. Generally, a change in the cost of unprocessed metal has
    a strong correlation to changes in the average selling price.
    Thus, as selling prices rose compared with the last year, so did
    the cost of unprocessed ferrous metal.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Auto Parts Business&#146; cost of goods sold increased
    $19&#160;million, or 42%, for the year ended August&#160;31,
    2005 as compared to the prior fiscal year. The higher cost of
    goods sold was primarily due to higher car purchase costs that
    resulted from higher scrap metal prices and the addition of
    seven new stores since the beginning of fiscal 2004. New stores
    that are not located in California tend to have higher cost of
    goods sold as a percentage of revenues. As a percentage of
    revenues, cost of goods sold increased from 56% to 59% as
    compared to the prior year due to higher car purchase costs and
    the addition of the seven new stores since the beginning of last
    year which earn a lower margin than the previously owned stores.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Steel Manufacturing Business&#146; cost of goods sold
    increased $27&#160;million, or 11%, to $269&#160;million. As a
    percentage of revenues, cost of goods sold decreased compared
    with fiscal 2004 from 89% to 85%. The average cost of goods sold
    per ton increased $76&#160;per ton, or 20%, compared to the
    prior year, which was primarily caused by higher raw material
    costs for recycled metal and alloys and an estimated
    $5&#160;million in costs resulting from the melt shop shut down
    in December 2004 to install the new furnace. The increase in
    cost of goods sold was more than offset by the $108&#160;per ton
    increase in average net selling price.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    37
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Revenues for the Joint Ventures in the Metals Recycling business
    segment in fiscal 2005 increased $660&#160;million, or 43%,
    compared with the same period last year, primarily due to 18%
    and 13% increases in average net selling prices per ton for the
    processing and trading businesses, respectively, and an 11%
    increase in the total volume of recycled ferrous metal sold over
    the prior year. The increase in the average net selling price
    per ton was due to the same supply and demand circumstances
    described earlier for the Company&#146;s wholly-owned businesses.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company&#146;s share of Joint Venture operating income for
    fiscal 2005 increased to $69&#160;million from $62&#160;million
    for fiscal 2004. In fiscal 2005, the processing joint ventures
    recorded year-end LIFO adjustments which increased operating
    income by $3&#160;million, while such adjustments reduced
    operating income by $6&#160;million in fiscal 2004.
    Additionally, these joint ventures experienced higher purchase
    prices for unprocessed metal, the effect of which was partially
    offset by increases in selling prices and volumes. The
    Company&#146;s share of joint venture operating income in fiscal
    2005 included a charge of $3&#160;million for its share of
    environmental costs. During the second quarter of fiscal 2005,
    in connection with the negotiation of the separation and
    termination of the Company&#146;s Metals Recycling Joint
    Ventures with Hugo Neu Corporation, the Company conducted an
    environmental due diligence investigation of certain joint
    venture businesses it agreed to acquire and identified certain
    environmental risks for which estimated remediation costs were
    accrued. The Company&#146;s share of operating income from the
    trading joint venture decreased from $11&#160;million in fiscal
    2004 to $9&#160;million in fiscal 2005, a 19% decrease.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On September&#160;30, 2005, the Company completed the separation
    and termination of its metals recycling joint ventures with HNC.
    See Note&#160;7, &#147;Business Combinations&#148;, of the Notes
    to Consolidated Financial Statements in Item&#160;8 Financial
    Statements and Supplementary Data for details of the agreement.
    Accordingly, fiscal 2006 only included one month of operating
    income for Joint Ventures in the Metals Recycling business.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Selling, General and Administrative
    Expense.</I>&#160;&#160;Compared with fiscal 2004, selling,
    general and administrative expense for this fiscal year
    increased $9&#160;million, or 19%. The increase is a result of
    increased salaries of $2&#160;million, increased legal and
    professional fees of $6&#160;million, the vesting of stock
    options for $1&#160;million, and increased selling and
    administrative costs of $3&#160;million for the Auto Parts
    Business segment, primarily related to new stores, offset by a
    $3&#160;million decrease in expense for the Company&#146;s bonus
    program. Approximately $1&#160;million of the increased salaries
    are related to the Auto Parts Business, primarily due to
    expansion of its management infrastructure to allow growth of
    this business segment. The increase in legal and professional
    fees is the result of approximately $4&#160;million incurred
    related to the investigations into the past practice of making
    improper payments to the purchasing managers of the
    Company&#146;s customers in Asia, as discussed in Note&#160;11,
    &#147;Commitments and Contingencies&#148;, of the Notes to
    Consolidated Financial Statements in Item&#160;8 Financial
    Statements and Supplementary Data, with an additional
    $2&#160;million spent on compliance with Sarbanes-Oxley,
    including increased independent audit fees and the use of
    outside experts to advise or assist the Company in various
    projects. The Company&#146;s bonus program considers
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    38
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    operating income, the utilization of operating assets and
    improvements over the prior year to determine bonus expense. The
    Company&#146;s anticipated bonus expense is less than the prior
    year because some of the Company&#146;s business segments&#146;
    results did not exceed targeted improvements in fiscal 2005 to
    the same extent as in fiscal 2004. As a percentage of revenues,
    selling, general and administrative expense has decreased by
    less than 1% due to spreading these expenses over higher
    revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Environmental Matters and Impairment
    Charges.</I>&#160;&#160;During fiscal 2005, the Company recorded
    environmental charges of $14&#160;million for additional
    estimated costs related to the ongoing remediation of the head
    of the Hylebos Waterway adjacent to the Company&#146;s Tacoma,
    Washington metal processing facility. An estimate of this
    liability was initially recognized as part of the 1995
    acquisition of the Tacoma facility. The cost estimate was based
    on the assumption that dredge removal of contaminated sediments
    would be accomplished within one dredge season during July
    2004&#160;&#151; February 2005. However, due to a variety of
    factors, including dredge contractor operational issues and
    other dredge related delays, the dredging was not completed
    during the first dredge season. As a result, the Company
    increased its environmental accrual by $14&#160;million
    primarily to account for additional estimated costs to complete
    this work during a second dredging season. The Company has filed
    a lawsuit against the dredge contractor to recover a significant
    portion of the increased costs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For a number of years prior to the Company&#146;s acquisition of
    Proler, Proler operated an industrial waste landfill in Texas,
    which Proler utilized to dispose of auto shredder residue from
    one of its operations. In August 2002, Proler entered the TCEQ
    VCP toward the pursuit of the VCP Certificate of Completion for
    the former landfill site. In fiscal 2005, TCEQ issued a
    Conditional Certificate of Completion, requiring the Company to
    perform on-going groundwater monitoring and annual inspections,
    maintenance and reporting. As a result of the resolution of this
    issue, the Company reduced its reserve related to this site by
    $2&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During fiscal 2002, the Company&#146;s Portland, Oregon metals
    recycling facility embarked on a dock and loading facility
    renovation. The renovation was suspended in fiscal 2003 when
    issues with the dock&#146;s substructure were detected. Upon
    review of new engineering designs focused on operational
    efficiency and safety specifications, an impairment charge of
    $4&#160;million was recorded in fiscal 2004 to write off
    renovation costs incurred prior to the suspension.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Interest Expense.</I>&#160;&#160;Interest expense for fiscal
    2005 decreased 59% to $1&#160;million compared with fiscal 2004.
    The decrease was a result of lower average debt balances during
    fiscal 2005 compared with fiscal 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Income Tax Provision.</I>&#160;&#160;The 35% tax rate for
    fiscal 2005 was higher than the 31% for fiscal 2004 primarily
    because the fiscal 2004 tax rate benefited from the final
    release of a valuation allowance that had previously offset net
    operating losses and minimum tax credit carryforwards. The 35%
    rate for fiscal 2005 approximates the 35% Federal statutory rate
    because projected Extraterritorial Income Exclusion benefits on
    export sales are largely offset by state income taxes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Liquidity
    and Capital Resources </FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Cash Flows.</I>&#160;&#160;The Company relies on cash
    provided by operating activities as a primary source of
    liquidity, supplemented by current cash resources, existing
    credit facilities and access to the capital markets. For fiscal
    2006, net cash provided by operating activities was
    $105&#160;million, compared to $146&#160;million in fiscal 2005
    and $74&#160;million in fiscal 2004. The $41&#160;million
    decline in cash from operating activities in 2006 compared to
    2005 was the result of lower net income of $4&#160;million and a
    decrease in the impact of non-cash items of $75&#160;million,
    offset by a smaller increase in working capital in fiscal 2006
    of $38&#160;million. The decrease in impact of non-cash items
    was primarily related to a non-cash gain from the disposition of
    joint venture assets in 2006 of $57&#160;million, tax benefits
    from employee stock options of $18&#160;million, a difference in
    environmental accruals of $12&#160;million and deferred taxes of
    $11&#160;million, offset by greater depreciation of
    $11&#160;million and a higher distribution of joint venture
    earnings of $12&#160;million. The lower increase in working
    capital in 2006 was primarily the result of a difference in
    accrued liabilities of $13&#160;million, prepaid expense and
    other current assets of $19&#160;million and higher accounts
    payable of $11&#160;million, offset by a greater increase in
    inventories of $35&#160;million, a decrease in accounts
    receivable of $7&#160;million and lower environmental liability
    of $5&#160;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    39
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The $72&#160;million increase in cash provided by operating
    activities in fiscal 2005 compared to 2004 was the result of
    higher net income of $36&#160;million and an increase in the
    impact of non-cash items of $100&#160;million offset by
    differences in the change in working capital of
    $64&#160;million. The increase in the impact of non-cash items
    was primarily related to the distribution of earnings in joint
    ventures of $64&#160;million, tax benefits from employee stock
    options of $14&#160;million and deferred taxes of
    $13&#160;million. The greater increase in cash used for working
    capital was primarily the result of changes in accrued
    liabilities of $21&#160;million, a reduction in environmental
    liabilities of $12&#160;million and increased pre-paid expenses
    and other current assets of $9&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For fiscal 2006, net cash used in investing activities was
    $198&#160;million compared to $72&#160;million in fiscal 2005
    and $47&#160;million in fiscal 2004. The $125&#160;million
    increase in cash outflows for investing activities in 2006
    compared to 2005 was primarily related to higher capital
    expenditures of $38&#160;million and acquisitions of
    $55&#160;million. The $25&#160;million increase in cash outflows
    for investing activities in 2005 compared to 2004 was primarily
    related to higher capital expenditures of $26&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For fiscal 2006, net cash provided by financing activities was
    $97&#160;million, compared to net cash used by financing
    activities of $65&#160;million in fiscal 2005 and
    $17&#160;million in fiscal 2004. The $161&#160;million increase
    in cash from financing activities in 2006 compared to 2005 was
    the result of the Company&#146;s increased borrowings in 2006,
    whereas the Company was repaying debt balances in 2005. The
    $47&#160;million decrease in cash from investing activities in
    fiscal 2005 compared to fiscal 2004 was primarily reflected in
    an increase in the Company&#146;s repayment of debt.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Capital Expenditures.</I>&#160;&#160;Capital expenditures
    totaled $87&#160;million, $48&#160;million and $22&#160;million
    for fiscal years 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. The
    increases in capital expenditures primarily reflect the
    Company&#146;s significant investments in modern equipment to
    improve the efficiency and capabilities of its businesses and to
    further enhance the Company&#146;s competitiveness. The capital
    expenditures in fiscal 2006 included $18&#160;million in partial
    payments for the installation of new mega-shredders at the
    Company&#146;s Oakland, California, Everett, Massachusetts and
    Portland, Oregon export facilities, $7&#160;million for major
    repairs to the dock at the Portland facility and
    $30&#160;million in other upgrades to equipment and
    infrastructure at the Company&#146;s Metals Recycling
    facilities. The Company also expended $7&#160;million for the
    conversion of five sites acquired in the GreenLeaf acquisition
    to the Company&#146;s self service store model, $10&#160;million
    for projects at the Company&#146;s steel manufacturing facility
    designed to improved efficiency and increase output and
    $7&#160;million to upgrade the Company&#146;s information
    technology infrastructure, including the installation of a new
    ERP system common to all the Company&#146;s operations. The
    Company anticipates that capital expenditures in fiscal 2007
    will total $81&#160;million. Capital projects are expected to
    include completion of the mega-shredder projects and
    modifications to the reheat furnace and billet yard craneway at
    the steel manufacturing facility. Additionally, the Company will
    incur expenditures to convert certain GreenLeaf stores from full
    service to self service and modernize stores in the Auto Parts
    Business and make further improvements to the Company&#146;s
    information technology infrastructure.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Accrued Environmental Liabilities.</I>&#160;&#160;Accrued
    environmental liabilities as of August&#160;31, 2006 were
    $41&#160;million, compared to $24&#160;million as of
    August&#160;31, 2005. The increases in environmental liabilities
    primarily reflect the Company&#146;s estimated environmental
    liabilities related to acquisitions made in fiscal 2006. Over
    the course of fiscal 2007, the Company expects to pay
    approximately $4&#160;million, primarily relating to previously
    accrued remediation projects in connection with one of its
    Metals Recycling facilities located in the State of Washington
    on the Hylebos Waterway. Additionally, the Company expects to
    require significant future cash outlays as it incurs the actual
    costs relating to the remediation of other such environmental
    liabilities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Debt.</I>&#160;&#160;On November&#160;8, 2005, the Company
    entered into an amended and restated committed unsecured bank
    credit agreement with the Bank of America, N.A., as
    administrative agent and lender and other lenders party thereto.
    The new agreement provides for a five-year, $400&#160;million
    revolving loan maturing in November 2010. The prior agreement
    had provided for a $150&#160;million revolving loan maturing in
    May 2006. Interest on outstanding indebtedness under the
    restated agreement is based, at the Company&#146;s option, on
    either LIBOR plus a spread of between 0.625% and 1.25%, with the
    amount of the spread based on a pricing grid tied to the
    Company&#146;s leverage ratio, or the higher of the prime rate
    or the federal funds rate plus 0.50%. In addition, annual
    commitment fees are payable on the unused portion of the credit
    facility at rates between 0.15% and 0.25% based on a pricing
    grid tied to the Company&#146;s leverage ratio. The Company also
    has an additional unsecured uncommitted credit line, which was
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    40
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    increased on March&#160;1, 2006, by $5&#160;million to
    $15&#160;million. Interest on outstanding indebtedness is set by
    the bank at the time of borrowing. Both credit agreements
    contain various representations and warranties, events of
    default and financial and other covenants, including covenants
    regarding maintenance of a minimum fixed charge coverage ratio
    and a maximum leverage ratio. As of August&#160;31, 2006, the
    Company had $95&#160;million of outstanding borrowings under
    these facilities and was in compliance with such covenants.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Acquisitions.</I>&#160;&#160;During fiscal 2006, the Company
    acquired several businesses, the purchases of which were funded
    by the Company&#146;s existing cash balances and credit
    facility. The Company, however, received $37&#160;million in
    cash in connection with the HNC joint venture separation and
    termination. In fiscal 2006, the Company completed the following
    acquisitions:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    September&#160;30, 2005, the Company received $37&#160;million
    in cash. The Company also received approximately
    $17&#160;million for previously undistributed earnings of the
    joint ventures.
</TD>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    On September&#160;30, 2005, the Company acquired GreenLeaf, five
    store properties leased by GreenLeaf and certain GreenLeaf debt
    obligations. Total consideration for the acquisition was
    $45&#160;million, subject to post-closing adjustments.
</TD>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

    <TD>    &#149;&#160;

    <TD align="left">    On October&#160;31, 2005, the Company acquired substantially all
    of the assets of Regional. The Company operates nine metals
    recycling facilities located in Georgia and Alabama, focused on
    nonferrous metals, with the assets acquired from Regional. The
    purchase price was $69&#160;million in cash including the
    assumption of certain liabilities.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

    <TD>    &#149;&#160;

    <TD align="left">    On March&#160;21, 2006 the Company purchased the minority
    interest in its MRL subsidiary. The Company took control of the
    MRL operations upon the separation and termination of its joint
    venture with HNC. MRL&#160;operates a metals recycling facility
    in Rhode Island. The purchase price of $25&#160;million was paid
    in cash.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Off-Balance
    Sheet Arrangements</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company is not a party to any off-balance sheet arrangements
    that have, or are reasonably likely to have, a current or future
    material effect on the Company&#146;s financial conditions,
    results of operations or cash flows.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Contractual
    Obligations and Commitments</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company has certain contractual obligations to make future
    payments. The following table summarizes these future
    obligations as of August&#160;31, 2006:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row -->
