<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;3&#160;&#151;
    Recent Accounting Pronouncements</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In November 2004, the Financial Accounting Standards Board
    (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;151,
    &#147;Inventory Costs, an amendment of ARB No.&#160;43,
    Chapter&#160;4&#148; (&#147;SFAS&#160;151&#148;). SFAS&#160;151
    clarifies the accounting for abnormal amounts of idle facility
    expense, freight, handling costs and wasted material (spoilage)
    should be recognized as current period charges. It also requires
    that allocation of fixed production overhead to the costs of
    conversion be based on the normal capacity of the production
    facilities. SFAS&#160;151 is effective for inventory costs
    incurred during fiscal years beginning after June&#160;15, 2005.
    The Company adopted SFAS&#160;151 on September&#160;1, 2005 with
    no material impact on the consolidated financial statements as
    the Company&#146;s previous policy mirrored the provisions of
    this pronouncement.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In December 2004, FASB issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;153,
    &#147;Exchanges of Nonmonetary Assets&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;153&#148;). SFAS&#160;153 explains that
    exchanges of nonmonetary assets should be measured based on the
    fair value of the assets exchanged. This statement is effective
    for fiscal years beginning after June&#160;15, 2005. The Company
    adopted SFAS&#160;153 during fiscal 2006 with no material impact
    on the consolidated financial statements at the time of adoption.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    58
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In December 2004, FASB issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123 (Revised
    2004), &#147;Shared-Based Payment&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;123(R)&#148;). SFAS&#160;123(R) supersedes
    Accounting Principles Board Opinion No.&#160;25,
    &#147;Accounting for Stock issued to Employees,&#148;
    (&#147;APB&#160;25&#148;) and amends SFAS&#160;95,
    &#147;Statement of Cash Flows&#148; (&#147;SFAS&#160;95&#148;).
    Under the standard, companies will no longer be able to account
    for stock-based employee compensation using the intrinsic method
    in accordance with APB&#160;25. Instead, SFAS&#160;123(R)
    requires the adoption of a fair-value method of accounting for
    stock-based employee compensation. SFAS&#160;123(R) is effective
    for the first interim reporting period of the first fiscal year
    beginning after June&#160;15, 2005. The Company adopted
    SFAS&#160;123(R), effective September&#160;1, 2005. The Company
    recognizes stock-based compensation expense over the requisite
    service period of the individual grants, which generally equals
    the vesting period. See Note&#160;2&#160;&#151; Summary of
    Significant Accounting Policies and Note&#160;13&#160;&#151;
    Stock Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In March 2005, FASB issued FASB Interpretation 47,
    &#147;Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement
    Obligations&#160;&#151; an Interpretation of FASB Statement
    No.&#160;143&#148; (&#147;FIN&#160;47&#148;). FIN&#160;47
    clarifies that the entity is required to record a liability in
    financial statements for the fair value of a conditional asset
    retirement obligation if the fair value of the liability can be
    reasonably estimated. The Company adopted FIN&#160;47 as of
    August&#160;31, 2006 with no material effect on the consolidated
    financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In June 2005, FASB issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;154,
    &#147;Accounting Changes and Error Corrections&#160;&#151; a
    replacement of APB No.&#160;20 and FASB Statement No.&#160;3
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;154&#148;). SFAS&#160;154 replaced APB
    No.&#160;20, &#147;Accounting Changes&#148; and FASB Statement
    No.&#160;3, &#147;Reporting Accounting Changes in Interim
    Financial Statements&#160;&#151; an amendment of APB Opinion
    No.&#160;28&#148;. This statement provides guidance on the
    accounting for and reporting of accounting changes and error
    corrections. It requires retrospective application to prior
    period&#146;s financial statements of changes in accounting
    principle, unless this would be impracticable. SFAS&#160;154
    also redefines the term &#147;restatement&#148; to mean the
    correction of an error by revising previously issued financial
    statements. This statement is effective for fiscal years
    beginning after December&#160;15, 2005. The Company intends to
    adopt this pronouncement for fiscal year 2007 and does not
    anticipate this standard to have a material impact on the
    consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In February 2006, FASB issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;155,
    &#147;Accounting for Certain Hybrid Financial Instruments&#148;,
    which is effective for all financial instruments acquired or
    issued after the beginning of an entity&#146;s first fiscal year
    that begins after September&#160;15, 2006. This Statement amends
    SFAS&#160;133, &#147;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and
    Hedging Activities,&#148; and FASB Statement No.&#160;140,
    &#147;Accounting for Transfers and Servicing of Financial Assets
    and Extinguishment of Liabilities&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;140&#148;). The Company intends to adopt this
    pronouncement for fiscal year 2008 and does not anticipate this
    pronouncement to have a material impact on the consolidated
    financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In March 2006, FASB issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;156,
    &#147;Accounting for Servicing of Financial Assets&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;156&#148;). This Statement amends SFAS&#160;140
    with respect to the accounting for separately recognized
    servicing assets and servicing liabilities. This Statement is
    effective for fiscal years beginning after September&#160;15,
    2006. The Company intends to adopt this pronouncement for fiscal
    year 2008 and does not anticipate this pronouncement to have a
    material impact on the consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In July 2006, FASB issued FASB Interpretation 48,
    &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes&#160;&#151; an
    interpretation of FASB Statement No.&#160;109&#148;
    (&#147;FIN&#160;48&#148;). This interpretation clarifies the
    accounting for uncertainty in income taxes recognized in an
    entity&#146;s financial statements in accordance with
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;109, &#147;Accounting for Income Taxes&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;109&#148;). It prescribes a recognition
    threshold and measurement attribute for financial statement
    recognition and disclosure of tax positions taken or expected to
    be taken on a tax return. This interpretation is effective for
    fiscal years beginning after December&#160;15, 2006. The Company
    will be required to adopt FIN&#160;48 in the first quarter of
    fiscal year 2008. Management is currently evaluating the
    requirements of the interpretation and has not yet determined
    the impact on the consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2006, FASB issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;157,
    &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; (&#147;SFAS&#160;157&#148;).
    SFAS&#160;157 defines fair value, establishes a framework for
    measuring fair value in GAAP, and expands disclosures about fair
    value measurements. SFAS&#160;157 is effective for financial
    statements issued for fiscal years beginning after
    November&#160;15,
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    59
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    2007, and interim periods within those fiscal years. Earlier
    application is encouraged, provided that the reporting entity
    has not yet issued financial statements for that fiscal year,
    including financial statements for an interim period within that
    fiscal year. The Company will be required to adopt SFAS&#160;157
    in the first quarter of fiscal year 2008. Management is
    currently evaluating the requirements of SFAS&#160;157 and has
    not yet determined the impact on the Company&#146;s consolidated
    financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2006, FASB issued SFAS&#160;No.&#160;158,
    &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for Defined Benefit Pension and
    Other Postretirement Plans, an amendment of FASB Statements
    No.&#160;87, 88, 106, and 132(R),&#148;
    (&#147;SFAS&#160;158&#148;). SFAS&#160;158 improves financial
    reporting by requiring an employer to recognize the over funded
    or under funded status of a defined benefit postretirement plan
    (other than a multiemployer plan) as an asset or liability in
    its statement of financial position and to recognize changes in
    that funded status in the year in which the changes occur
    through comprehensive income of a business entity. The Company
    is generally required to initially recognize the funded status
    of a defined benefit postretirement plan and to provide the
    required disclosures as of the end of the fiscal year ending
    after December&#160;15, 2006 or as of the end of the fiscal year
    2007. The Company is required to adopt the requirement to
    measure plan assets and benefit obligations as of
    August&#160;31, 2009. Management is currently evaluating the
    requirements of SFAS&#160;158 and has not yet determined the
    impact on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In September 2006, the SEC staff issued staff Accounting
    Bulletin No.&#160;108, &#147;Considering the Effects of Prior
    Year Misstatements when Quantifying Misstatements in current
    Year financial statements&#148; (&#147;SAB&#160;108&#148;).
    SAB&#160;108 was issued in order to eliminate the diversity of
    practice surrounding how public companies quantify financial
    statement misstatements. Traditionally, there have been two
    widely-recognized methods for quantifying the effects of
    financial statement misstatements: the &#147;roll-over&#148;
    method and the &#147;iron curtain&#148; method. Under the new
    model, commonly referred to as the &#147;dual approach&#148;,
    quantification of errors are required under both the iron
    curtain and the roll-over methods. SAB&#160;108 permits existing
    public companies to initially apply its provisions either by (i)
    restating prior financial statements as if the &#147;dual
    approach&#148; had always been used or (ii) recording the
    cumulative effect of initially applying the &#147;dual
    approach&#148; as adjustments to the carrying values of assets
    and liabilities as of January&#160;1, 2006 with an offsetting
    adjustment recorded to the opening balance of retained earnings.
    The Company is currently reviewing the impacts of this
    pronouncement, but believes it will not have a material impact
    on its financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;4&#160;&#151;
    Inventories</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Inventories consisted of the following at August&#160;31:
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Depreciation expense for property, plant and equipment was
    $29&#160;million, $20&#160;million, and $20&#160;million for
    fiscal years 2006, 2005, and 2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;6&#160;&#151;
    Investment in and Advances to Joint Ventures</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During fiscal 2004, 2005 and through September&#160;30, 2005 of
    fiscal 2006, the Company had investments in nine joint ventures
    in which it owned 50% of the joint venture interests. These
    joint ventures were accounted for under the equity method of
    accounting and presented as a separate reportable segment. As a
    result of the Hugo Neu Corporation (&#147;HNC&#148;) separation
    that was completed on September&#160;30, 2005 (See
    Note&#160;7&#160;&#151; Business Combinations), the Joint
    Venture segment was eliminated and the results for the two
    entities acquired in this transaction that the Company is now
    managing, as well as the remaining five joint venture interests,
    are consolidated into the Metals Recycling Business. As such,
    the current year joint venture amounts are not presented
    separately for segment reporting purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following tables present summarized financial information
    for the Company&#146;s joint ventures in which the Company was a
    partner:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;7&#160;&#151;
    Business Combinations</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Hugo
    Neu Corporation Separation and Termination Agreement
    </FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On September&#160;30, 2005, the Company, HNC and certain of
    their subsidiaries closed a transaction to separate and
    terminate their metal recycling joint venture relationships. The
    Company received the following as a result of the HNC joint
    venture separation and termination:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="99%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    Prolerized New England Company (&#147;PNE&#148;), which
    comprised the joint ventures&#146; various interests in the
    Northeast processing and recycling operations that primarily
    operate in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Maine;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    The assets and related liabilities of Hugo Neu Schnitzer Global
    Trade related to a scrap metal business in parts of Russia and
    the Baltic region, including Poland, Denmark, Finland, Norway
    and Sweden. The Company entered into a non-compete agreement
    from HNC that bars it from buying scrap metal in certain areas
    in Russia and the Baltic region for a five-year period ending on
    June&#160;8, 2010;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    THS Recycling LLC, dba&#160;Hawaii Metals Recycling Company
    (&#147;HMR&#148;), a Hawaii Metals Recycling business that was
    previously owned 100% by HNC;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    A payment received from HNC of $37&#160;million in cash.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    HNC received the following as a result of the HNC joint venture
    separation and termination:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="99%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    The joint venture operations in New York, New Jersey and
    California, including the scrap metal processing facilities,
    marine terminals and related ancillary satellite sites, the
    interim New York City recycling contract, and other
    miscellaneous assets;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    The assets and related liabilities of Hugo Neu Schnitzer Global
    Trade that are not related to the Russian and Baltic region.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In accordance with ARB 51, the Company elected to consolidate
    the results of two of the businesses acquired through the HNC
    separation and termination agreement as though the transaction
    had occurred at the beginning of fiscal 2006, instead of the
    acquisition date. These businesses were partially owned prior to
    this acquisition.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The divestiture of the Company&#146;s interest in the joint
    ventures with HNC enabled the Company to expand its metals
    recycling operations in the Northeastern United States and
    Hawaii. In addition, the divestiture removed restrictions on the
    Company pursuing additional acquisition opportunities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Purchase accounting has been finalized and a dispute exists
    between the Company and HNC over post closing adjustments. The
    Company believes they have adequately accrued for this dispute.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In accordance with SFAS&#160;141 &#147;Business
    Combinations&#148;, the purchase price of the assets acquired
    and liabilities assumed under the separation and termination
    agreement is the fair value of the joint venture interests given
    up as part of the exchange as well as related acquisition costs.
    Accordingly, the purchase price is $165&#160;million, including
    acquisition costs of $6&#160;million. Upon divestiture of the
    joint venture interests, a $57&#160;million gain resulted from
    the difference between the fair value of $159&#160;million and
    the carrying value associated with the disposed joint venture
    interests. There was a net increase to the gain of
    $2&#160;million that was recorded in the fourth quarter that was
    based on final purchase accounting adjustments.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The purchase price was allocated to tangible and identifiable
    intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on
    their respective fair values as estimated by management of the
    Company with the assistance of an independent appraiser. The
    excess of the aggregate purchase price over the fair value of
    the identifiable net assets acquired of $56&#160;million was
    recognized as goodwill. Goodwill in the amount of
    $7&#160;million existed on the joint ventures&#146; balance
    sheets prior to the separation and termination, but was not
    shown separately on the Company&#146;s balance sheet as part of
    investment in joint ventures. In addition, Goodwill in the
    amount of $1&#160;million was
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    62
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    consolidated in the Company&#146;s balance sheet, but was owned
    by minority interests in Metals Recycling, LLC (&#147;MRL&#148;)
    as of September&#160;30, 2005. Therefore, the total increase to
    goodwill related to the HNC separation and termination agreement
    was $63&#160;million as of September&#160;30, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    September&#160;30, 2005 for the assets acquired and liabilities
    assumed on the date of the acquisition (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">GreenLeaf
    Acquisition</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On September&#160;30, 2005, the Company acquired GreenLeaf Auto
    Recyclers, LLC (&#147;GreenLeaf&#148;), five properties
    previously leased by GreenLeaf and certain GreenLeaf debt
    obligations. GreenLeaf is engaged in the business of auto
    dismantling and recycling and sells its products primarily to
    collision and mechanical repair shops. GreenLeaf currently
    operates in three wholesale sales and distribution offices and
    15 commercial locations throughout the United States. The
    acquisition of GreenLeaf significantly expanded the
    Company&#146;s national presence in the business of auto
    dismantling and recycling. In addition, the acquisition enabled
    the Company to enter into the full service segment of the
    recycling auto parts market that services commercial customers.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total purchase price for the GreenLeaf acquisition, including
    acquisition costs of $1&#160;million, was $45&#160;million, paid
    in cash. The purchase price of the GreenLeaf acquisition was
    allocated to tangible and identifiable intangible assets
    acquired and liabilities assumed based on their respective fair
    values as estimated by management of the Company with the
    assistance of an independent appraiser. The excess of the
    aggregate purchase price over the fair values of the
    identifiable net assets acquired of $5&#160;million was
    recognized as goodwill.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following is a summary of the fair values, for the assets
    acquired and liabilities assumed on the date of the acquisition
    (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="94%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->
    <TD width="2%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=hang1 -->

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The acquisition of GreenLeaf was a stock purchase which included
    Federal net operating losses (&#147;NOLs&#148;) of
    $15&#160;million that will expire in the years 2022 through 2024
    if not used before then. The Company&#146;s use of these NOLs is
    restricted under Federal income tax law to $1&#160;million a
    year.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Regional
    Recycling Acquisition</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;31, 2005, the Company purchased substantially
    all of the assets of Regional Recycling LLC
    (&#147;Regional&#148;) for $69&#160;million in cash, including a
    working capital adjustment of $3&#160;million and acquisition
    costs of $500 thousand. Using the assets acquired from Regional,
    the Company operates nine Metals Recycling facilities located in
    the states of Georgia and Alabama, which process ferrous and
    nonferrous scrap metal without the use of shredders. The
    acquisition of Regional provided the Company with a presence in
    the growing market in the Southeastern United States. In
    addition, the acquisition of Regional enhanced the
    Company&#146;s ability to service domestic, and eventually,
    export markets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The purchase price in the Regional acquisition was allocated to
    tangible and identifiable intangible assets acquired and
    liabilities assumed based on their respective fair values as
    estimated by management of the Company with the assistance of an
    independent appraiser. The excess of the aggregate purchase
    price over the fair values of the identifiable net assets
    acquired of approximately $28&#160;million was recognized as
    goodwill.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following is a summary of the fair values as of
    October&#160;31, 2005, for the assets acquired and liabilities
    assumed on the date of the acquisition (in millions):
</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Acquisition
    of Minority Interest in Metals Recycling, LLC</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As a part of its joint venture relationship with HNC, the
    Company indirectly owned a 30% interest in MRL; a Rhode Island
    based metal recycling business, with HNC and a minority interest
    owning the remaining 30% and 40%, respectively. On
    September&#160;30, 2005, when the Company closed the transaction
    to separate and terminate its joint venture relationship with
    HNC, it obtained HNC&#146;s 30% ownership interest. Accordingly,
    the net assets of MRL relating to the 30% ownership obtained
    from HNC were adjusted to fair value on the date of separation
    and termination of joint venture interests. The net assets of
    MRL owned by the 40% minority interests were recorded at
    carrying value as of the date of the HNC separation and
    termination agreement, including $1&#160;million of historical
    goodwill.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On March&#160;21, 2006, the Company purchased the remaining 40%
    minority interest in MRL for $25&#160;million. The acquisition
    of the 40% minority interest enabled the Company to fully
    leverage its investments in PNE and MRL, which competed in the
    same geographic regions, by operating as one business to
    optimize facilities and increase
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    64
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Summary
    of Acquisitions</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The total aggregate goodwill recognized from the acquisitions in
    fiscal 2006 amounted to $115&#160;million. In accordance with
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;142, &#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible
    Assets&#148; (&#147;SFAS&#160;142&#148;) goodwill is not
    amortized and will be tested for impairment at least annually.
    Goodwill recognized in connection with the HNC separation and
    termination, the Regional acquisition and the acquisition of
    minority interest in MRL is deductible for tax purposes, whereas
    the goodwill recognized in connection with GreenLeaf is not.
    Payment of the consideration for the recently acquired
    businesses was funded by the Company&#146;s existing cash
    balances and credit facility net of the $37&#160;million in cash
    received in the HNC separation and termination.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following presents the details of identifiable intangible
    assets acquired and the unamortized value as of August&#160;31,
    2006:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Excluded from the table above are backlog intangible assets of
    $1&#160;million, which were acquired in connection with the HNC
    separation and termination of joint venture interests. Backlog
    intangible assets represent revenue to be gained for orders
    placed prior to acquisition. Backlog intangible assets are
    written-off to cost of goods sold as the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    65

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    related inventory is sold. During the year, all inventory
    related to backlog intangible assets was sold and, therefore, no
    backlog intangible asset remained as of August&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Acquired covenant not to compete asset represents agreements
    between a sales broker and Schnitzer Global Exchange, key
    employees and GreenLeaf and prior owners of Regional and MRL.
    Acquired leasehold interests asset represents net favorable
    lease terms that were in place prior to the acquisition.
    Acquired supply contract asset represents a supply agreement
    between Ford Motor Company and GreenLeaf that is expected to
    continue for an additional five years. Acquired tradename asset
    has a 20&#160;year useful life as it has been registered, used
    and protected for a considerable amount of time, and there is no
    indication from the management that it will be discontinued. The
    Company performs reviews for impairment of all its purchased
    amortizable intangible assets whenever events or changes in
    circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may
    not be recoverable. As of August&#160;31, 2006, management
    concluded there was no indication of events or changes in
    circumstances indicating that the carrying amount of purchased
    intangible assets may not be recoverable.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with the HNC separation and termination and the
    GreenLeaf and Regional acquisitions, the Company conducted
    environmental due diligence reviews of the acquired assets.
    Based on the information obtained in the reviews performed
    during the first quarter of fiscal 2006, in conjunction with
    purchase accounting, the Company accrued $25&#160;million in
    environmental liabilities for probable and reasonably estimable
    future remediation costs at the acquired facilities. During the
    second quarter of fiscal 2006, the Company incurred remediation
    costs of $1&#160;million related to these acquired companies. No
    environmental proceedings are pending with respect to any of the
    facilities acquired in these acquisitions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    though the acquisitions under the HNC separation and termination
    and the GreenLeaf and Regional acquisitions had occurred as of
    the beginning of the periods presented (in thousands, except per
    share amounts):
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Excluded from the table above are backlog intangible assets of
    $1&#160;million, which was acquired in connection with the HNC
    separation and termination of joint venture interests. Backlog
    intangible assets represent revenue to be gained for orders
    placed prior to acquisition. Backlog intangible assets are
    written-off to cost of goods sold as the related inventory is
    sold. During the year, all inventory related to backlog
    intangible assets was sold and therefore there was no backlog
    intangible asset at August&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The changes in the carrying amount of goodwill by reporting
    segment for the year ending August&#160;31, 2006 are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The total intangible amortization expense for the year ended
    August&#160;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004 was $2&#160;million,
    $1&#160;million, and $1&#160;million, respectively. The
    estimated amortization expense, based on current intangible

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;9&#160;&#151;
    Impairment Charges</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During fiscal 2002, the Company embarked on a dock and loading
    facility renovation at its Portland, Oregon metal recycling
    facility. The renovation was suspended in fiscal 2003 when
    issues with the dock&#146;s substructure were detected. Upon
    review of new engineering designs focused on operational
    efficiency and safety specifications, an impairment charge of
    $4&#160;million was recorded in the fourth quarter of fiscal
    2004 to write-off renovation costs incurred prior to the
    suspension. There were no impairment charges recorded in fiscal
    2006 or 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;10&#160;&#151;
    Long-Term Debt</FONT></U></B>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of August&#160;31, 2006, the Company had a committed
    unsecured bank credit facility totaling $400&#160;million
    maturing in November 2010 and bearing interest at varying
    interest rates. Interest is payable at varying dates not to
    exceed the maturity of each advance under the line. Interest on
    outstanding indebtedness under the credit facility is based, at
    the Company&#146;s option, on either LIBOR plus a spread of
    between 0.625% and 1.25%, with the amount of the spread based on
    a pricing grid tied to the Company&#146;s leverage ratio, or the
    higher of the prime rate or the federal funds rate plus 0.50%.
    In addition, annual commitment fees are payable on the unused
    portion of the credit facility at rates between 0.15% and 0.25%
    based on a pricing grid tied to the Company&#146;s leverage
    ratio.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition to the above facility, the Company has an additional
    uncommitted unsecured line of credit totaling $15&#160;million.
    There were no outstanding borrowings against the unsecured line
    of credit at August&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The committed bank credit facilities and other borrowings
    contain various representations and warranties, events of
    default and financial and other covenants, including covenants
    regarding maintenance of a minimum fixed coverage ratio and a
    maximum leverage ratio. As of August&#160;31, 2006, the Company
    was in compliance with all such covenants.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    68
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;11&#160;&#151;
    Commitments and Contingencies</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Commitments</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company leases a portion of its capital equipment and
    certain of its facilities under operating leases that expire at
    various dates through December&#160;26, 2029. Rent expense was
    $13&#160;million, $8&#160;million and $7&#160;million for fiscal
    years 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. See discussion of
    leases with related parties in Note&#160;16&#160;&#151; Related
    Party Transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Steel Manufacturing Business has a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">take-or-pay</FONT>
    natural gas contract that requires a minimum purchase of
    3,500&#160;Million British Thermal Units (&#147;MMBTU&#148;) per
    day at tiered pricing, whether or not the amount is utilized.
    Effective April&#160;1, 2006, the natural gas rate increased to
    $7.85&#160;per MMBTU from $6.90&#160;per MMBTU. The contract
    expires on May&#160;31, 2009. The Steel Manufacturing Business
    also has an electricity contract with McMinnville Water and
    Light that requires a minimum purchase of electricity at a rate
    subject to variable pricing, whether or not the amount is
    utilized. The contract expires in September 2011.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The table below sets forth the Company&#146;s future minimum
    obligations under non-cancelable operating leases from unrelated
    parties, service obligations and purchase commitments as of
    August&#160;31, 2006:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
