<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Contingencies-Environmental</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company considers various factors when estimating its
    environmental liabilities. Adjustments to the liabilities are
    made when additional information becomes available that affects
    the estimated costs to study or remediate any
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    69
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    environmental issues. The factors which the Company considers in
    its recognition and measurement of environmental liabilities
    include the following:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="99%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    Current regulations both at the time the reserve is established
    and during the course of the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">clean-up</FONT>
    which specify standards for acceptable remediation;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    Information about the site, which becomes available as the site
    is studied and remediated;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    The professional judgment of both senior-level internal staff
    and external consultants, who take into account similar, recent
    instances of environmental remediation issues, among other
    considerations;
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    Technologies available that can be used for remediation;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    The number and financial condition of other potentially
    responsible parties and the extent of their responsibility for
    the remediation.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Metals
    Recycling Business</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with acquisitions in the Metals Recycling Business
    in 1995 and 1996, the Company recorded in its financial
    statements reserves for environmental liabilities previously
    recorded by the acquired companies. Environmental reserves are
    evaluated quarterly according to Company policy. On
    August&#160;31, 2006, environmental reserves for the Metals
    Recycling Business aggregated $23&#160;million, which is
    primarily comprised of the reserves established during recent
    acquisitions and the Hylebos Waterway Remediation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Hylebos Waterway Remediation.</I>&#160;&#160;General Metals
    of Tacoma (&#147;GMT&#148;), a subsidiary of the Company, owns
    and operates a metal recycling facility located in the State of
    Washington on the Hylebos Waterway, a part of Commencement Bay,
    which is the subject of an ongoing remediation project by the
    United States Environmental Protection Agency (&#147;EPA&#148;)
    under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and
    Liability Act (&#147;CERCLA&#148;). GMT and more than 60 other
    parties were named potentially responsible parties
    (&#147;PRPs&#148;) for the investigation and
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">clean-up</FONT> of
    contaminated sediment along the Hylebos Waterway. On
    March&#160;25, 2002, the EPA issued Unilateral Administrative
    Orders (&#147;UAOs&#148;) to GMT and another party (&#147;Other
    Party&#148;) to proceed with Remedial Design and Remedial Action
    (&#147;RD/RA&#148;) for the head of the Hylebos and to two other
    parties to proceed with the RD/RA for the balance of the
    waterway. The UAO for the head of the Hylebos Waterway was
    converted to a voluntary consent decree in 2004, pursuant to
    which GMT and the Other Party agreed to remediate the head of
    the Hylebos Waterway.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    There are two phases to the remediation of the head of the
    Hylebos Waterway. The first phase was the intertidal and bank
    remediation, which was conducted in 2003 and early 2004. The
    second phase is dredging in the head of the Hylebos Waterway,
    which commenced in July 2005 and was completed in February 2006.
    During fiscal 2005, the Company paid remediation costs of
    $16&#160;million related to Hylebos dredging which resulted in a
    reduction of the recorded environmental liability. The
    Company&#146;s cost estimates were based on the assumption that
    dredge removal of contaminated sediments would be accomplished
    within one dredge season during July 2004&#160;&#151; February
    2005. However, due to a variety of factors, including dredge
    contractor operational issues and other dredge related delays,
    the dredging was not completed during the first dredge season.
    As a result, the Company recorded environmental charges of
    $14&#160;million in fiscal 2005 primarily to account for
    additional estimated costs to complete this work during a second
    dredging season. During fiscal 2006, the Company incurred
    remediation costs of $7&#160;million, which was charged to the
    environmental reserves, and on August&#160;31, 2006,
    environmental reserves for the Hylebos Waterway aggregated
    $4&#160;million. The Company and the Other Party have filed a
    complaint in the United States District Court for the Western
    District of Washington against the dredge contractor to recover
    damages and a significant portion of cost over runs incurred in
    the second dredging season to complete the project.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    GMT and the Other Party are pursuing settlement negotiations and
    legal actions against other non-settling, non-performing PRPs to
    recover additional amounts that may be applied against the head
    of the Hylebos remediation costs. During fiscal 2005, the
    Company recovered $1&#160;million from four non-performing PRPs.
    This amount had
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    70
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    previously been taken into account as a reduction in the
    Company&#146;s reserve for environmental liabilities.
    Uncertainties continue to exist regarding the total cost to
    remediate this site as well as the Company&#146;s share of those
    costs; nevertheless, the Company&#146;s estimate of its
    liabilities related to this site is based on information
    currently available.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Natural Resource Damage Trustees (&#147;Trustees&#148;) for
    Commencement Bay have asserted claims against GMT and other PRPs
    within the Hylebos Waterway area for alleged damage to natural
    resources. In March 2002, the Trustees delivered a draft
    settlement proposal to GMT and others in which the Trustees
    suggested a methodology for resolving the dispute, but did not
    indicate any proposed damages or cost amounts. In June 2002, GMT
    responded to the Trustees&#146; draft settlement proposal with
    various corrections and other comments, as did twenty other
    participants. In February 2004, GMT submitted a settlement
    proposal to the Trustees for a complete settlement of Natural
    Resource Damage liability for the GMT site. The proposal
    included three primary components: (1)&#160;an offer to perform
    a habitat restoration project; (2)&#160;reimbursement of Trustee
    past assessment costs; and (3)&#160;payment of Trustee oversight
    costs. The parties have reached agreement on the terms of the
    settlement, which is subject to final agency approval. The
    Company&#146;s previously recorded environmental liabilities
    include an estimate of the Company&#146;s potential liability
    for these claims.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Washington State Department of Ecology named GMT, along with
    a number of other parties, as Potentially Liable Parties
    (&#147;PLPs&#148;) for a site referred to as Tacoma Metals. GMT
    operated on this site under a lease until 1982. The property
    owner and current operator have taken the lead role in
    performing a RI/FS for the site. The Company&#146;s previously
    recorded environmental liabilities include an estimate of the
    Company&#146;s potential liability at this site.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Portland Harbor.</I>&#160;&#160;In December 2000, the EPA
    designated the Portland Harbor, a 5.5&#160;mile stretch of the
    Willamette River in Portland, Oregon, as a Superfund site. The
    Company&#146;s metals recycling and deep water terminal facility
    in Portland, Oregon is located adjacent to the Portland Harbor.
    The EPA has identified at least 69&#160;PRPs, including the
    Company and Crawford Street Corporation (&#147;CSC&#148;), a
    subsidiary of the Company, which own and operate or formerly
    owned and operated sites adjacent to the Portland Harbor
    Superfund site. The precise nature and extent of any
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">clean-up</FONT> of
    the Portland Harbor, the parties to be involved, the process to
    be followed for such a clean-up, and the allocation of any costs
    for the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">clean-up</FONT>
    among responsible parties have not yet been determined. It is
    unclear whether or to what extent the Company or CSC will be
    liable for environmental costs or damages associated with the
    Superfund site. It is also unclear whether or to what extent
    natural resource damage claims or third party contribution or
    damages claims will be asserted against the Company, as such, a
    reserve has been established. While the Company and CSC
    participated in certain preliminary Portland Harbor study
    efforts, they are not parties to the consent order entered into
    by the EPA with other PRPs (&#147;Lower Willamette Group&#148;
    or (&#147;LWG&#148;) for a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility
    Study (&#147;RI/FS&#148;)); however, the Company and CSC could
    become liable for a share of the costs of this study at a later
    stage of the proceedings.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Separately, the Oregon Department of Environmental Quality
    (&#147;DEQ&#148;) has requested operating history and other
    information from numerous persons and entities which own or
    conduct operations on properties adjacent to or upland from the
    Portland Harbor, including the Company and CSC. The DEQ
    investigations at the Company and CSC sites are focused on
    controlling any current releases of contaminants into the
    Willamette River. The Company has agreed to a voluntary Remedial
    Investigation/Source Control effort with the DEQ regarding its
    Portland, Oregon deep water terminal facility and the site
    formerly owned by CSC. DEQ identified these sites as potential
    sources of contaminants that could be released into the
    Willamette River. The Company believes that improvements in the
    operations at these sites, often referred to as Best Management
    Practices (&#147;BMPs&#148;), will provide effective source
    control and avoid the release of contaminants from these sites
    and has proposed to DEQ the implementation of BMPs as the
    resolution of this investigation. Additionally, the EPA recently
    released and made available to the public the LWG&#146;s
    &#147;Round Two&#148; data, involving hundreds of sediment
    samples taken throughout the six mile harbor site. The Company
    is in the process of reviewing this data.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The cost of the investigations and remediation associated with
    these properties and the cost of employment of source control
    BMPs is not reasonably estimable until the completion of the
    data review. While the Company has
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    71
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    recorded a liability for its estimated share of the costs of the
    investigation incurred by the LWG to date, no liability has been
    recorded for either future investigation costs or remediation of
    the Portland Harbor.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During fiscal 2006, the Company and CSC, together with
    approximately 27 PRPs who are not participating in the
    LWG&#146;s RI/FS, received letters from the LWG and one of its
    members with respect to participating in the LWG&#160;RI/FS and
    potential claims for past costs and cost allocation and
    reimbursement. If the Company or CSC&#160;declines to
    participate in the continued implementation of the RI/FS, it is
    possible that they could be the subject to EPA or DEQ
    enforcement orders or litigation by the LWG or its members. The
    Company is cooperating in discussions with the agencies and the
    LWG and continuing to evaluate alleged liabilities in context of
    the available technical, factual and legal information.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During fiscal 2006, the Company incurred immaterial amounts of
    legal fees relating to the Portland Harbor and has reserved
    approximately $1&#160;million for both the federal and state
    reviews.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Other Metals Recycling Business Sites.</I>&#160;&#160;For a
    number of years prior to the Company&#146;s 1996 acquisition of
    Proler International Corp. (&#147;Proler&#148;), Proler operated
    a shredder with an
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">on-site</FONT>
    industrial waste landfill in Texas, which Proler utilized to
    dispose of auto shredder residue (&#147;ASR&#148;) from the
    operations. In August 2002, Proler entered the Texas Commission
    on Environmental Quality (&#147;TCEQ&#148;) Voluntary Cleanup
    Program (&#147;VCP&#148;) toward the pursuit of a VCP
    Certificate of Completion for the former landfill site. In
    fiscal 2005, TCEQ issued a Conditional Certificate of
    Completion, requiring the Company to perform on-going
    groundwater monitoring and annual inspections, maintenance, and
    reporting. As a result of the resolution of this issue, the
    Company reduced its reserve related to this site by
    $2&#160;million in fiscal 2005. In fiscal 2006, the Company paid
    immaterial amounts of costs relating to this site. Reserves
    related to this site at August&#160;31, 2006 were
    $1&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During the second quarter of fiscal 2005, in connection with the
    negotiation of the separation and termination agreement relating
    to the Company&#146;s metals recycling joint ventures with HNC
    (See Note&#160;7&#160;&#151; Business Combinations), the Company
    conducted an environmental due diligence investigation of
    certain joint venture businesses it proposed to acquire. As a
    result of this investigation, the Company identified certain
    environmental risks and accrued $3&#160;million for its share of
    the estimated costs to remediate these risks upon completion of
    the separation, which was included in the consolidated
    statements of operations in fiscal 2005. During the first
    quarter of fiscal 2006, an additional $12&#160;million was
    recorded, in conjunction with purchase accounting, representing
    the remaining portion of the environmental liabilities
    associated with the HNC separation and termination agreement as
    well as the Regional acquisitions. During 2006, $1&#160;million
    of costs were incurred and as of August&#160;31, 2006,
    $14&#160;million related to these acquisitions remains in
    reserves as total remediation is not complete. No environmental
    compliance proceedings are pending with respect to any of these
    sites.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition to the matters discussed above, the Company&#146;s
    environmental reserve includes amounts for potential future
    cleanup of other sites at which the Company or its acquired
    subsidiaries have conducted business or allegedly disposed of
    other materials. None of these are material, individually or in
    the aggregate.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Auto
    Parts Business</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    From fiscal 2003 through the first quarter of fiscal 2006, the
    Company completed four acquisitions of businesses in the Auto
    Parts Business segment. At the time of each acquisition, the
    Company conducted an environmental due diligence investigation
    related to locations involved in the acquisition. As a result of
    the environmental due diligence investigations, the Company
    recorded a reserve for the estimated cost to address certain
    environmental matters. The reserve is evaluated quarterly
    according to the Company policy. On August&#160;31, 2006,
    environmental reserves for the Auto Parts Business aggregated
    $18&#160;million, which includes an environmental reserve for
    the GreenLeaf acquisition. No environmental enforcement
    proceedings are pending with respect to any of these sites and
    no amounts were charged to these reserves in fiscal 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In January 2004, the Auto Parts Business was served with a
    Notice of Violation (&#147;NOV&#148;) of the general permit
    requirements on its diesel powered car crushers at the Rancho
    Cordova and Sacramento locations from the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    72
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Sacramento Metropolitan Air Quality Management District
    (&#147;SMAQMD&#148;). Since receiving the NOV, the Sacramento
    and Rancho Cordova locations have converted their diesel powered
    car crushers to electric powered. The Company settled this
    matter which resulted in payment of a fine to SMAQMD during the
    Company&#146;s fourth fiscal quarter in 2005. The settlement
    amount was less than the $1&#160;million the Company had
    previously reserved for this matter.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Steel
    Manufacturing Business</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Steel Manufacturing Business&#146; electric arc furnace
    generates dust (&#147;EAF dust&#148;), which is classified as
    hazardous waste by the EPA because of its zinc and lead content.
    The EAF dust is shipped via specialized rail cars to a firm in
    the United States that applies a treatment that allows the EAF
    dust to be delisted as hazardous waste so it can be disposed of
    as a non-hazardous, solid waste.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Steel Manufacturing Business has an operating permit issued
    under Title&#160;V of the Clean Air Act Amendment of 1990, which
    governs certain air quality standards. The permit was first
    issued in 1998 and has since been renewed through the year 2007.
    During fiscal 2006, the Company submitted its application for
    renewal of the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">5-year</FONT>
    permit. The permit allows the Steel Manufacturing Business to
    produce up to 900,000 tons of billets per year and allows
    rolling mill production levels which vary based on levels of
    emissions.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Contingencies-Other</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company had a past practice of making improper payments to
    the purchasing managers of nearly all of the Company&#146;s
    customers in Asia in connection with export sales of recycled
    ferrous metal. The Company stopped this practice after it was
    advised in 2004 that it raised questions of possible violations
    of U.S. and foreign laws. Thereafter, the Audit Committee was
    advised and conducted a preliminary compliance review. On
    November&#160;18, 2004, on the recommendation of the Audit
    Committee, the Board of Directors authorized the Audit Committee
    to engage independent counsel and conduct a thorough,
    independent investigation. The Board of Directors also
    authorized and directed that the existence and the results of
    the investigation be voluntarily reported to the
    U.S.&#160;Department of Justice (&#147;DOJ&#148;) and the
    &#147;SEC&#148;, and that the Company cooperate fully with those
    agencies. The Audit Committee notified the DOJ and the SEC of
    the independent investigation, engaged outside counsel to assist
    in the independent investigation and instructed outside counsel
    to fully cooperate with the DOJ and the SEC and to provide those
    agencies with the information obtained as a result of the
    independent investigation. On October&#160;16, 2006, the Company
    finalized settlements with the DOJ and the SEC resolving the
    investigation. Under the settlement, the Company agreed to a
    deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ (the &#147;Deferred
    Prosecution Agreement&#148;) and agreed to an order, issued by
    the SEC, instituting
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">cease-and-desist</FONT>
    proceedings, making findings, and imposing a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">cease-and-desist</FONT>
    order pursuant to Section&#160;21C of the Securities Exchange
    Act of 1934 (the &#147;Order&#148;). Under the Deferred
    Prosecution Agreement, the DOJ will not prosecute the Company if
    the Company meets the conditions of the agreement for a period
    of three years including, among other things, that the Company
    engage a compliance consultant to advise its compliance officer
    and its Board of Directors on the Company&#146;s compliance
    program. Under the Order, the Company agreed to cease and desist
    from the past practices that were the subject of the
    investigation and to disgorge $8&#160;million of profits and
    prejudgment interest. The Order also contains provisions
    comparable to those in the Deferred Prosecution Agreement
    regarding the engagement of the compliance consultant. In
    addition, under the settlement, the Company&#146;s Korean
    subsidiary, SSI International Far East, Ltd., pled guilty to
    Foreign Corrupt Practices Act anti-bribery and books and records
    provisions, conspiracy and wire fraud charges and paid a fine of
    $7&#160;million. These amounts were accrued during fiscal 2006
    and the investigation settlement did not affect the
    Company&#146;s previously reported financial results. Under the
    settlement, the Company has agreed to cooperate fully with any
    ongoing, related DOJ and SEC investigations. The Company has
    incurred expenses, and may incur further expenses, in connection
    with the advance of funds to, or indemnification of, individuals
    involved in such investigations.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    73
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company and HNC were the 50% members of Hugo Neu Schnitzer
    Global Trade, LLC (&#147;HNSGT&#148;), a joint venture engaged
    in global trading of recycled metal. HNC managed the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">day-to-day</FONT>
    activities of HNSGT. In January 2004, HNC advised the Company
    that it would charge HNSGT a 1% commission on HNSGT&#146;s
    recycled metal sales, and began deducting those commissions.
    While some reasonable reimbursement of HNC&#146;s costs might
    have been appropriate, the Company responded that the 1%
    commission was excessive and that HNC had no authority to
    unilaterally impose such commissions on HNSGT. As of
    August&#160;31, 2005, the Company estimated that its 50% share
    of the disputed commissions totaled $6&#160;million. In
    recording operating income from joint ventures, the Company has
    excluded from joint venture expenses the excess of these
    disputed commissions over the Company&#146;s estimate of
    reasonable reimbursements. As part of the separation and
    termination of the Company&#146;s joint ventures with HNC (See
    Note&#160;7&#160;&#151; Business Combinations), the Company
    agreed to release its claim for reimbursement of the excess
    commissions which resulted in a reduction of the gain recorded
    upon the HNC disposition.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;12&#160;&#151;
    Employee Benefits</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Defined
    Contribution Plans</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company has several defined contribution plans covering
    nonunion employees. The pension cost related to these plans
    totaled $2&#160;million, $1&#160;million and $1&#160;million for
    fiscal 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. The increase from 2005
    to 2006 was the result of contributions to deferred contribution
    plans related to the Company&#146;s acquisitions in fiscal 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Defined
    Benefit Pension Plan</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For certain nonunion employees, the Company maintains a defined
    benefit pension plan. As of May&#160;16, 2006, the Company
    formally made the decision to cease benefits in, or freeze the
    defined benefit plan, with an effective date of June&#160;30,
    2006. The defined benefit plan freeze qualifies as a plan
    curtailment under Statement of Financial Accounting Standards
    No.&#160;88, &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for Settlements
    and Curtailments of Defined Benefit Plans and for Termination of
    Benefits&#148; (&#147;SFAS&#160;88&#148;). In accordance with
    SFAS&#160;88, the Company recognized an insignificant
    curtailment loss equal to the unrecognized prior service cost
    associated with the years of service no longer expected to be
    rendered as the result of the curtailment.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    74
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Weighted-average assumptions used to determine net periodic
    pension benefit cost for years ended August&#160;31:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    To determine the expected long-term rate of return on pension
    plan assets, the Company considers the current and expected
    asset allocations, as well as historical and expected returns on
    various categories of plan assets. The Company applies the
    expected rate of return to a market related value of the assets
    which reduces the underlying variability in assets to which the
    Company applies that expected return. The Company amortizes
    gains and losses, as well as the effects of changes in actuarial
    assumptions and plan provisions over a period no longer than the
    average future service of employees. The average remaining
    service period is 14.8&#160;years.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Actuarial assumptions.</I>&#160;&#160;Primary actuarial
    assumptions are determined as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="99%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    The expected long-term rate of return on plan assets is based on
    our estimate of long-term returns for equities and fixed income
    securities weighted by the allocation of assets in the plans.
    The rate is impacted by changes in general market conditions,
    but because it represents a long-term rate, it is not
    significantly impacted by short-term market swings. Changes in
    the allocation of plan assets would also impact this rate.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    The assumed discount rate is used to discount future benefit
    obligations back to today&#146;s dollars. The U.S.&#160;discount
    rate is reflective of yield rates on long-term investment grade
    corporate bonds in and around the August&#160;31 valuation date.
    A test of reasonableness was performed by comparing the results
    with those obtained from applying discounts derived from the
    spot rate developed for the Citigroup Pension Yield Curve as of
    August 31, 2006 to the year-by-year expected benefit payments.
    Liabilities determined from the single rate method were within
    3% of those determined by the yield curve method. This rate is
    sensitive to changes in interest rates. A decrease in the
    discount rate would increase our obligation and expense.
</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">    The expected rate of compensation increase is used to develop
    benefit obligations using projected pay at retirement. This rate
    represents average long-term salary increases and is influenced
    by our compensation policies. An increase in this rate would
    increase our obligation and expense. Effective June&#160;30,
    2006, the Company ceased the accrual of further benefits under
    the plan and the expected rate of future compensation increase
    is no longer applicable in calculating benefit obligations.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Plan asset allocations.</I>&#160;&#160;The Company&#146;s
    asset allocation for its pension plan is based on the primary
    goal of maximizing investment returns over the long-term. At the
    same time, the Company has invested in a diversified portfolio
    so as to provide a balance of returns and risk. In an effort to
    quantify this allocation, the Company&#146;s Plan Committee has
    established a target guideline to be used in determining the
    investment mix.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The table below shows the Company&#146;s target allocation range
    along with the actual allocations at August&#160;31:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Multiemployer
    Pension Plans</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In accordance with collective bargaining agreements, the Company
    contributed to multiemployer pension plans $3&#160;million per
    year during fiscal 2006, 2005, and 2004. The Company is not the
    sponsor or administrator of these multiemployer plans.
    Contributions were determined in accordance with provisions of
    negotiated labor contracts.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company learned during fiscal 2004 that one of the
    multiemployer plans of the Steel Manufacturing Business would
    not meet Employee Retirement Incentive Security Act of 1974
    (&#147;ERISA&#148;) minimum funding standards for the plan year
    ending September&#160;30, 2004. The trustees of that plan
    applied to the Internal Revenue Service for certain relief from
    this minimum funding standard. The Internal Revenue Service
    (&#147;IRS&#148;) indicated a willingness to consider granting
    the relief provided the plan&#146;s contributing employers,
    including the Company, agree to increased contributions. The
    increased contributions were estimated to
    average&#160;6%&#160;per year, compounded annually, until the
    plan reaches the funded status required by the IRS. These
    increases were based on the Company&#146;s current contribution
    level to the plan of approximately $2&#160;million per year.
    Based on commitments from the majority of employers
    participating in the Plan to make the increased contributions,
    the Plan Trustees proceeded with the relief request, and in
    August 2006 received formal approval from the IRS. Based on this
    approval, in the fourth fiscal quarter of 2006, the Company
    reversed approximately $1&#160;million in charges that had been
    accrued in fiscal 2004 for the Company&#146;s estimated share of
    additional contributions or excise taxes that would have been
    required had the IRS approval not been received.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    77
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Other
    Benefits</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company has adopted a nonqualified supplemental retirement
    plan (&#147;SERP&#148;) for certain executives. A restricted
    trust fund has been established and invested in life insurance
    policies which can be used for plan benefits, but are subject to
    claims of general creditors. The trust fund is classified as
    other assets and the pension liability is classified as other
    long-term liabilities. The status of this plan is summarized as
    follows as of August&#160;31 and for the year then ended:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The trust fund assets stock market gains and losses are included
    in other income (expense). During fiscal 2006, 2005 and 2004,
    the Company recognized gains totaling $29 thousand, $177
    thousand and $105 thousand, respectively. In fiscal 2006, 2005
    and 2004, the Company contributed $189 thousand, $1 thousand and
    $1 thousand, respectively, to the plan. As an unfunded plan,
    contributions are defined as benefit payments made to plan
    beneficiaries.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;13&#160;&#151;
    Stock Incentive Plan</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company has adopted the 1993 Stock Incentive Plan
    (&#147;Plan&#148;) for its employees, consultants, and
    directors. Pursuant to the provisions of the Plan, as amended,
    the Company is authorized to issue up to 7,200,000&#160;shares
    of Class&#160;A Common Stock for any awards issued under the
    Plan. At the 2006 Annual Meeting of Shareholders held on
    January&#160;30, 2006, the Company&#146;s shareholders approved
    amendments to the Plan to (a)&#160;authorize the grant of
    performance-based long-term incentive awards
    (&#147;performance-based awards&#148;) under the Plan that would
    be eligible for treatment as performance-based compensation
    under Section&#160;162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986
    and (b)&#160;increase the per-employee limit on grants of
    options and stock appreciation rights under the Plan from
    100,000&#160;shares to 150,000&#160;shares annually. The
    amendments did not include any increase in the number of shares
    reserved for issuance under the Plan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As a result of adopting SFAS&#160;123(R), the Company&#146;s
    income before taxes and minority interests for fiscal 2006 was
    lower by $3&#160;million. Similarly, the Company&#146;s net
    income for fiscal 2006 was lower by $2&#160;million more than
    the amounts that would have been reported by the Company had it
    continued to account for stock-based compensation under
    APB&#160;25. No compensation costs associated with share-based
    payments has been capitalized as part of the cost of an asset as
    of August&#160;31, 2006. The impact on both basic and diluted
    net income per share for fiscal 2006 was $0.06&#160;per share.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In accordance with the applicable provisions of
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123(R) and FASB Staff Position (FSP)
    FAS&#160;No.&#160;123(R)-3 issued on November&#160;10, 2005, the
    Company elected to use the short-form method to calculate the
    Windfall tax pool (&#147;Windfall&#148;) as of September&#160;1,
    2005, against which any future deficiency in actual tax benefits
    from exercises of stock options as compared to tax benefits
    recorded under SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123(R), defined as shortfall,
    will be offset. As of September&#160;1, 2005, the Windfall
    calculated in accordance with the provisions of
    FSP&#160;FAS&#160;No.&#160;123(R)-3 amounted to $11&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to the adoption of SFAS&#160;123(R), the Company presented
    the tax benefits from employee stock option plan as operating
    cash flows. Upon the adoption of SFAS&#160;123(R), tax benefits
    in excess of the compensation expense recognized for those
    options are classified as financing cash inflows.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    78
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Stock
    Options</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Under the Plan, stock options are granted to employees at
    exercise prices equal to the fair market value of the
    Company&#146;s stock at the dates of grant at the sole
    discretion of the Board of Directors. Generally, stock options
    vest ratably over a five-year period from the date of grant and
    have a contractual term of ten years. The fair value of each
    option grant under the Plan was estimated at the date of grant
    using the Black-Scholes Option Pricing Model
    (&#147;Black-Scholes&#148;), which utilizes assumptions related
    to volatility, the risk-free interest rate, the dividend yield,
    and employee exercise behavior. Expected volatilities utilized
    in the model are based on the historical volatility of the
    Company&#146;s stock price. The risk-free interest rate is
    derived from the U.S.&#160;Treasury yield curve in effect at the
    time of grant. The expected lives of the grants are based on
    historical exercise patterns and post-vesting termination
    behavior.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As described above, the fair value of stock options granted
    during the following years ended August&#160;31 was determined
    using the Black-Scholes with the following assumptions:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of August&#160;31, 2006 and August&#160;31, 2005, the total
    number of unvested stock options was 654,000&#160;shares and
    498,000&#160;shares, respectively. The aggregate intrinsic value
    in the table above represents the total pre-tax intrinsic value
    that would have been received by the option holders had all
    option holders exercised their options on August&#160;31, 2006.
    Aggregate intrinsic value was calculated as the difference
    between the Company&#146;s closing stock price on the last
    trading day of fiscal 2006 and the exercise price, multiplied by
    the number of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">in-the-money</FONT>
    options. Total intrinsic value of stock options exercised was
    $12&#160;million, $4&#160;million, and $22&#160;million for the
    years ended August&#160;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004, respectively.
    The total fair value of stock options vested during the fiscal
    years ended August&#160;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004 was
    $2&#160;million, $1&#160;million, and $1&#160;million,
    respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company recognized compensation expense associated with
    stock options of $2&#160;million for fiscal 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of August&#160;31, 2006, the total remaining unrecognized
    compensation expense related to non-vested stock options
    amounted to $9&#160;million. The weighted-average remaining
    requisite service period of the non-vested stock options was
    approximately 38&#160;months.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    79
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total proceeds received from option exercises for the years
    ended August&#160;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004 was $4&#160;million,
    $1&#160;million, and $7&#160;million, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The tax benefits realized from the option exercises of the
    share-based payment awards for fiscal 2006 were $4&#160;million.
    In fiscal year 2005, the Company recorded cumulative tax
    benefits from exercises of employee stock options of
    $14&#160;million from deducting or planning to deduct, on
    original or amended income tax returns, the amounts the
    employees would report as ordinary income.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In connection with stock option awards by the Compensation
    Committee on July&#160;25, 2006, the Compensation Committee
    authorized the Company to permit option grantees to elect to
    receive the value of the option award in restricted shares of
    Class&#160;A common stock of the Company. In October 2006, the
    Company commenced a tender offer under which the recipients of
    the July 25 option grants were afforded the opportunity to
    exchange the options for restricted stock units
    (&#147;RSUs&#148;) on a 2:1 basis. The exchange ratio was
    determined using a Black-Sholes pricing model such that the
    values at the time of exchange were equivalent. The RSUs vest on
    the same schedule as the options would have vested.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Long-Term
    Incentive Plan</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Subject to shareholder approval of proposed amendments to the
    Plan, on November&#160;29, 2005 the Company&#146;s Compensation
    Committee approved performance-based awards under the Plan and
    the entry by the Company into Long-Term Incentive Award
    Agreements evidencing those awards. Shareholder approval of the
    Plan amendments on January&#160;30, 2006 satisfied the condition
    to the effectiveness of the awards. The Compensation Committee
    approved additional awards on the same terms to two executive
    officers and one officer in a division on January&#160;30, 2006
    and April&#160;28, 2006, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Compensation Committee established a series of performance
    targets, which include the Company&#146;s total shareholder
    return (&#147;TSR&#148;) for the performance period relative to
    the S&#38;P 500 Industrials (weighted at 50%) (&#147;TSR
    Awards&#148;), the operating income per ton of the
    Company&#146;s Metals Recycling Business for the performance
    period (weighted at
    16<FONT style="vertical-align: top; font-size: 70&#37;">2</FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 70&#37;">3</FONT>%),
    the number of Economic Value Added (&#147;EVA&#148;) positive
    stores of the Auto Parts Business for the last year of the
    performance period (weighted at
    16<FONT style="vertical-align: top; font-size: 70&#37;">2</FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 70&#37;">3</FONT>%),
    and the man hours per ton of the Steel Manufacturing Business
    for the performance period (weighted at
    16<FONT style="vertical-align: top; font-size: 70&#37;">2</FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 70&#37;">3</FONT>%),
    corresponding to award payouts ranging from 25% to 300% of the
    weighted portions of the target awards (&#147;Performance
    Awards,&#148; collectively). For participants who work
    exclusively in one business segment, the awards are weighted 50%
    on the performance measure for their segment and 50% on total
    shareholder return. A participant generally must be employed by
    the Company on October&#160;31 following the end of the
    performance period to receive an award payout, although
    pro-rated awards will be paid if employment terminates earlier
    on account of death, disability, retirement, termination without
    cause after the first year of the performance period, or a sale
    of the Company or the business segment for which a participant
    works. Awards will be paid in the Company&#146;s Class&#160;A
    Common Stock as soon as practicable after October&#160;31
    following the end of the performance period.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The fair value of Performance Awards granted during the periods
    was determined by multiplying the total number of shares
    expected to be issued by the Company&#146;s closing stock price
    as of the date of the grant and is being recognized over the
    requisite service period of 2.9&#160;years. The weighted average
    fair value of Performance Awards granted during fiscal 2006 was
    $34.27. Weighted average expected life of Performance Awards
    granted during fiscal 2006 was 2.9&#160;years.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    80
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of August&#160;31, 2006, there were no vested LTIP awards.
    Compensation expense associated with Performance Awards for
    fiscal 2006 was calculated assuming all performance targets were
    met. The total compensation expense associated with Performance
    Awards and TSR Awards amounted to $1&#160;million for fiscal
    2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Deferred
    Stock Units</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On July&#160;26, 2006, the Board of Directors, on the
    recommendation of its Compensation Committee, approved the
    Deferred Compensation Plan for Non-Employee Directors in
    conjunction with authorizing the issuance of Deferred Stock
    Units (&#147;DSUs&#148;) to non-employee directors as the form
    of the restricted stock awards approved by the Board in July
    2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    DSUs will be awarded to non-employee directors pursuant to the
    Plan. One DSU gives the director the right to receive one share
    of Class&#160;A Common Stock at a future date. Annually,
    immediately following the annual meeting of shareholders
    (commencing with the 2007 annual meeting), each non-employee
    director will receive DSUs for a number of shares equal to
    $87,500 divided by the closing market price of the Class&#160;A
    Common Stock on the grant date. The DSUs will become fully
    vested on the day before the next annual meeting, subject to
    continued service on the Board. The DSUs will also become fully
    vested on the death or disability of a director or a change in
    control of the Company (as defined in the DSU award agreement).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    After the DSUs have become vested, directors will be credited
    with additional whole or fractional shares to reflect dividends
    that would have been paid on the stock subject to the DSUs. The
    Company will issue Class&#160;A Common Stock to a director
    pursuant to vested DSUs in a lump sum in January after the
    director ceases to be a director of the Company, subject to the
    right of the director to elect an installment payment program
    under the Company&#146;s Deferred Compensation Plan for
    Non-Employee Directors.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In order to move from a cycle of granting non-employee director
    equity awards each year in June to a cycle of granting the
    awards in January at the time of the annual meeting, the Company
    will grant a one-time award of DSUs
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    81
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SCHNITZER
    STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.<BR>
    </FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NOTES&#160;TO
    CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
    STATEMENTS&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    to each non-employee director, effective as of August&#160;31,
    2006. The DSUs will become fully vested on the day before the
    2007 annual meeting, subject to continued Board service. The
    one-time grants will be for the number of DSUs equal to $43,750
    ($65,625 for the Chairman of the Board) divided by the closing
    market price of the Class&#160;A Common Stock on August&#160;31,
    2006. On August&#160;31, 2006, the total number of DSUs granted
    was 14,000&#160;shares.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The compensation expense associated with the DSUs granted will
    be recognized over the respective requisite service periods of
    the awards.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000003">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    Income tax expense differs from the amounts that would result by

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The 37% tax rate for fiscal 2006 is higher than the 35% for
    fiscal 2005 primarily because this year&#146;s effective tax
    rate has been increased by the $14&#160;million of nondeductible
    penalties and profits disgorgement expensed in connection with
    the making of improper payments to purchasing managers of nearly
    all of the Company&#146;s customers in Asia (see Item&#160;3,
    Legal Proceedings). Secondarily, the current year
    $57&#160;million gain from the disposition of joint venture
    interests (see Note&#160;7&#160;&#151; Business Combinations)
    will not likely benefit from either the Extraterritorial Income
    Exclusion on export sales or the Section&#160;199 domestic
    manufacturing deduction that reduces the Company&#146;s
    effective tax rate on other operating income.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Neither the fiscal 2006 nor 2005 tax rates benefited as did the
    fiscal 2004 tax rate from the earlier year&#146;s release of
    valuation allowances that had previously offset $15&#160;million
    of federal net operating losses (&#147;NOLs&#148;) and
    $1&#160;million of minimum tax credit carryforwards. Both the
    NOLs and credit carryforwards had accompanied the Company&#146;s
    1996 acquisition of Proler International Corp. The valuation
    allowances had been originally established because management
    was uncertain whether Federal tax law would ultimately constrain
    their use. Each fiscal year management has assessed the
    continuing need for the valuation allowances, and determined in
    fiscal year 2004 that the remaining $6&#160;million of valuation
    reserves pertaining to NOLs and tax credits could be released
    because it was more likely than not that future taxable income
    and tax would be sufficient to absorb them. This determination
    was based upon a number of factors such as profitability trends,
    industry fundamentals and recent profitable acquisitions. The
    release of the valuation reserves had no effect on cash flows.
    The Company had no valuation allowance as of August&#160;31,
    2006 or 2005. The Company has $15&#160;million of federal NOLs
    which arose from the acquisition of GreenLeaf. These will expire
    in years 2022 through 2024 and the use is restricted to
    $1&#160;million per year.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    83
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;15&#160;&#151;
    Earnings and Dividends Per Share</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Basic net income per share is computed based upon the weighted
    average number of common shares outstanding during the period.
    Diluted net income per share reflects the potential dilution
    that would occur if securities or other contracts to issue
    common stock were exercised or converted into common stock using
    the treasury stock method. The following represents a
    reconciliation from basic net income per share to diluted net
    income per share at August&#160;31:
</DIV>
